ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: The class helped me delve into queer and theory and history from Stonewall to the present. The material is varied and per the "multidimensional" aspect of the name, explains the intersection of many different identities within the community.
I learned a lot about the history of queer and trans movements in the black community throughout the mid 1900's to the current day.
I learned a lot about queer and trans rights like the Stonewall riot.

You learn about the history of queer and trans politics. You learn about community formation, neoliberalism, the occlusions in dominant forms of queer history, and the queer people of color who led and continue to lead the charge.
I really enjoyed the hats skills training, helped me better understand how to evaluate and understand new texts
We learned about the histories of S
an intersectional overview of the origin and development of what we can now call the modern queer social movement, new ways of thinking (in the De Bono's 6 thinking hats and such)
I learned more about the histories of queer and trans movements and resistance, as well as the many artistic forms that these movements utilized.
This course is incredibly. I particularly enjoyed the use of "the hats" which encouraged students to use all types of learning and tools to analyse the different topics.

I learned a lot about the history of queer abolition through many different lenses (information, creative, etc.) and under Professor Ferguson's and my TA Minh Vu's extrapolation of how the movement teaches us lessons that speak to the larger movement of living and of life. I learned a lot about myself and my position in society and how much there is to discover in the politics of living.
Ability to produce work in new, creative formats that I had never heard of before.
Learned about the history of Transexuality and so much more! Each class was incredibly enlightening and educating about trans politics and life.

Very comprehensive and intersectional study of queer history from the AIDS crisis to the present, with many historical connections and new insights that helped my own understanding of queerness and queer studies.
Everything. This course taught me the most important things Ive learned my whole time at Yale.
Super close reading of short texts, attention to oral histories, creative application and connections-making to historical concepts
I learned so much in the area of queer studies, queer theory, and queer of color practices. I also learned how to engage with text in an effective way.
Got to explore the intersectionality of race, sexuality, and gender throughout history, which was very valuable and something Ive never gotten the chance to do.
Knowledge about history of trans and queer politics.
Knowledge of queer and trans historical figures of color. Learning in nontraditional ways  video/artistic media, peer collaboration, Prof. Ferguson's analysis "hats"
I learned some new approaches to conceptualizing queer history, especially in the form of the nonlinear and non-product-oriented approaches to learning employed by Professor Ferguson and my TA.
Queer history and analyzing archives in different ways.

I learned a lot about multi-issue politics, direct action, and the dangers of single-issue politics historically and today. I learned a lot about the key activist players before, around, and after the time of stonewall, as well as the shifting of movements centered in the 70s and 80s.
Knowledge and insight on the gay, trans, and black experience.
I learned a lot about queer theory and history, and how it interacts with other movements. It was extremely interesting and moving t times.

I learned about histories of movements for queer liberation. The course managed to be simultaneously very broad (looking at multiple movements, events, activists, texts, etc) while also very detailed & informative. I learned about using different lenses to examine texts and to get as  much as possible out of reading theory and manifestos
I learned a lot about how the histories of several social movements are linked. I also learned a lot about queer and trans politics from the readings, lectures, and discussion section.
I learned so much about the rich history of community and organizing by and for queer communities of color.
I learned more about queer history as well as how to look beneath the surface of a text/piece of media.
This class taught me so much about queer and trans liberation movements in the US and the power that art and media can have.

This is one of the few courses surrounding queer history that are taught at Yale. The course readings are thoughtfully chosen and I overall really enjoyed being able to have an opportunity to learn about queerness and its intersection with other oppressed identities.
I learned a lot about intersectional Queer history, mainly in the united states, and I developed more perspective and tools for discussing these issues.
Learned a lot about the history of queer poc in politics. A wide breadth of movements and people.

I learned a lot about how to think about the recent history of queerness and transness and the way that we can think of that history in the context of the present day. I also felt like this class did a great job in teaching me to do the work that I felt compelled to do instead of the work that I had to do, and that did wonders for my mental health.
Learned more about queer history, activism, and the implications this has on making change now.

I learned about the Six Hats method which helped me engage with text and media in an effective way. I gained greater insight into LGBTQ history with the intersectional approach we had throughout the semester.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The course had just made the jump from a seminar to a lecture and it was quite clear. Professor Ferguson wanted to keep the interactive element of the course alive, but many students did not participate in the lecture setting as actively as they would in a seminar. The material is interesting and relevant from writers of many different identities regarding many varying themes throughout the semester. Sections fell short for me and seemed to be tangential, in a bad way, to discussions we had in class.

The course is very well organized and engages in a lot of thoughtful literature and art relevant to the course. The course also does not assign irrelevant or meaningless busy work which I appreciated.

Strength - The assignments were genuinely fun and interesting to accomplish. 
Weakness - None
Professor Ferguson is a wonderful lecturer. I also really loved my section!

The class is amazing. 10/10. Take the class if you want to learn about queer and trans politics. Professor Ferguson's as well as the TAs' investment in the class is clear by the quality and care of the instruction.

Weakness: can be a lot of work if you're not interested in the material.

unfortunately, people didnt seem to do the readings or attend lecture regularly sometimes awkward pauses where no one would speak up in lecture but I really loved the material and Prof Ferguson is a brilliant lecturer

This class is by far one of the best I have taken at Yale! This history covered in this class is one is often excluded from other gender and sexuality classes, and does a great job of challenging some of the mainstream narratives in LGBTQ history. The assignments did a great job of engaging the theory we learned in class and pushing our analytical skills, while at the same time feeling like relatively low-stress assignments. One of our assignments was to conceptualize a nightlife space. I also appreciated the open ended nature of the final project, and the option to pursue a creative project.

strengths: the class is low-stakes and the teaching staff genuinely cares about learning rather than the formal academic conventions that tend to stress people out, super accommodating, great chill way to learn something new
weaknesses: felt like it was hard to maintain engagement in lecture and also it didn't feel like there was much actual intellectual discussion in discussion section or lecture (as there was no real diversity of viewpoints discussed, such as those that were on the opposing side, etc.)

I had heard great things about this course so honestly felt a little disappointed why what I felt was not a structure most conducive to learning. A lot of the readings were about the same person, same moment in history, and centered around the same themes, so I felt like I learned one or two concepts really well (concepts that I was already well-versed in before starting this course) instead of learning more about the specific intricacies and nuances of this time. I'd love to see a reading list that is better organized and lectures with a common theme throughout that clearly show the purpose of each reading. I also didn't love the discussion format of lecture- I much rather would have heard Professor Ferguson's insights during class and used section to discuss amongst ourselves, as it was often the same few people raising their hands.
Strengths: Everything. The professor, the material, the workload, the topics. Truly outstanding course.

The course's biggest strength was structurally embodying the values that it identified through its literature. The class felt like a reflection of our desires and hopes a posteriori to learning about queer abolition's desires and imagination for ourselves. It was very forgiving and generous and insightful. A very rare and personally valuable course. My TA in particular, Minh Vu, was an incredible teacher. His feedback on our assignments showed so much insight and care.

The readings of this course are fantastic.

However, the lectures are inaccessible and unegaging. Very few people show up to lecture because they are hard to follow and not grounded in much material.
No weaknesses at all! This was the most perfect class Ive ever taken!

This is an excellent course - it engages so many different queer creations and historical threads, and is very well-structured for student success! I'd honestly say my only recommendation for improvement might be to have more regular opportunities for engagement with Professor Ferguson, who really made an impact on me.
Strengths: readings, Professor, lecture style, TFs, videos, thought and care

As much as a strength is that this course is super accessible to a variety of students due to short readings and comprehensive lectures, I think a weakness was that there was little accountability for students to even do the minimal readings that there were. Asking for student participation in a large lecture hall was also a bit intimidating and led to awkward silences, where it wasn't clear what level of analysis or interpretation or mere observation was being asked.

strengths: amazing tfs and professor, amazing readings, well-organized course, emphasis on learning and not grades, engaging lectures 

weakness: my only critique of the course is I wished we'd had some more small group discussions in lecture. I loved how people spoke out in class but I wish we had been able to speak with those around us more.

Professor Ferguson is wonderful and really passionate; I appreciated that the emphasis in this class was on learning to adopt a more creative mindset when approaching the readings and the final project, which was very open-ended and incredibly rewarding. One thing I will say is that this class feels like it should remain a seminar. I know that due to student demand, this class was expanded and converted into a lecture, but I think that the way Professor Ferguson leads classes by encouraging and fostering student dialogue/discussion is catered more towards students who are more outgoing and have already engaged in the material in past coursesit felt like the same students were always participating in each class. I think I was expecting more of a lecture-style class in which the professor gave a chronological recounting of the history, as opposed to providing context for and explaining the readings. With the way that this class is currently structured, I believe that a small seminar would allow more student engagement with the materials and bring more voices into the conversation.
Very good
Super awesome course, would recommend.
Strengths: amazing course, empathetic instructors, flexibility in assignments

Professor Ferguson is an INCREDIBLE presence, and delivers more engaging and thoughtful lectures than anyone I have ever seen: it was an honor to hear his insights. The content of this course is well-curated and delivers a solid overview of the complex histories of queer community organizing since Stonewall, especially in its focus on intersectionality and QPOC experiences. I will say that if you have a solid understanding of this history already, you won't learn much from this course, but it's worth it just to hear Professor Ferguson talk.
Only strengths. I will cherish this class.

I think that Professor Ferguson brought in a lot of interesting primary sources and texts that helped me dive into concepts like multi-issue politics and direct action. However, I wish the course had more of a flow/historical order to it. Sometimes it felt like we were just circling around the same topics/ideas over and over again, rather than learning how ideas built on each other over time/shifted through the decades.
Strengths were the interesting information and the care for students shown by the instructor, even in a large lecture.

Strengths: The lower workload of the class was incredible in facilitating true learning. Most Yale courses inundate students with work such that the student does not fully have time to process the material and engage with it. The readings were amazingly and expertly chosen. Section leaders were very understanding and kind. Professor Ferguson is very knowledgable.
Weaknesses: None.

I think both a strength and weakness of the course is that your engagement with it is largely determined by how much you want to engage! There's a lot of flexibility and room for creativity which I think is really amazing, and also offers a lot of space to imagine what education can mean and look like. I really loved the class, so I did all of the readings, went to lecture, section... but never felt stressed or overwhelmed by it. I wonder, though, what it would be like to have more opportunities to apply learning built into the class (maybe in a way that involves writing or creating something, getting feedback). I'm not sure if it would add to or take away from the impact of the class, because I know in some ways the class is constructed to avoid that, but I worry a little about my ability to apply the content, theory, etc. that I learned.

Strengths: Prof  Ferguson an amazing lecturer, the texts were engaging
Weaknesses: none

The class is very well-designed. Each reading was relevant to the courses main argument, and the work load was one of the most manageable workloads that I have had during my time at Yale. Professor Ferguson was a very engaging lecturer and had us learn from a variety of materials, including articles, movies, and photos.
Strengths are in the material covered and the tracking. I think there could be more classmate  interaction.

Everything about this class is a strength!! Definitely an amazing professor who cares so much about the students and wants us to do well, TAs who were wonderfully chosen and made sections fun, light workload with flexibility on assignments. No weaknesses at all

The assignments are low lift while engaging and allowed me to be creative. Professor Ferguson as well as the TFs all emphasize self-care and are understanding when it comes to attendance and deadlines.

I enjoyed the structure of the course. I thought it was designed for students to take as much away from it as they decided to, and for me I really enjoyed going to lecture and discussion section and was able to do so without being too stressed about the work or my performance. I think the structure really allowed me to take in the material.
It was a wonderful course, perhaps a bit repetitive. The writing was great, it felt like you had time to try to do a good job. It felt like it was designed for us to do well.
Amazing flexibility and understanding. This is how a class should be run.
The light workload allowed for more engagement with the class lectures and material.

I really appreciated how the coursework was organized in this class. It allowed students to go at their own pace of learning instead of constantly making them fear losing an A in the class.  I also found lectures very engaging and full of different mediums such as movies, clips, and music. Sometimes student engagement was hard to get because it is a bigger lecture. I think it might help to have students discuss with their peers a bit and then have people participate.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would, but you need to engage with the material to enjoy the course. TAs are a little hit or miss, so take that with a grain of salt, but the course does have the potential to be very rewarding.
I would recommend this course to another student interested in social justice history since the professor was very knowledgeable and engaged with his material.
I would, one of the best courses I have taken at Yale.
Yes, absolutely! This class really made me think. The professor and TAs also prioritize student wellbeing/mental health, which was really refreshing and something I'm very grateful for.
Yes! 10/10 great class. Professor Ferguson and the TAs were amazing. Prof. Ferguson is an amazing lecturer and the TAs were some of the best TAs I've had at Yale.
Yes!

I would absolutely recommend this class to any student at Yale. The class is structured in a way that is remarkably accessible, and does a great job of exploring histories of LGBTQ resistance in a way that is both digestible and not reductive. Professor Ferguson and the TFs are some of the most accommodating instructors I've encountered.

Yeah, it's a very chill way to learn more about a topic that has become more and more prominent in social politics over time. But be wary that this is mainly just for overview rather than any real critical discussion about the topics

I still would recommend it because I think it's filling an important gap in Yale's curriculum, but I think it needs to be substantially improved and is not filling that gap to the best of its ability.
YES!!! Take it. I promise it's amazing. Take it as a fifth credit. Great learning.
I would highly recommend taking this class. It is the kind of class that mobilizes the best parts of Yale, in my opinion. I have so much respect for this course and its instructors.

No. I really wanted to like this course (so badly), but it's taught in such a confusing way and I took very few concrete lessons away from it. I don't know anyone that felt engaged and fulfilled by this class.
Not only would I recommend this course, but I mention it in every conversation I have surrounding class selection! You have to take this class!
Yes! This is a great class, not a difficult workload at all, and the history is so important and complex that I'd recommend this to whoever has room for it in their schedule.
YES a thousand times yes. You must take this course. It is the best course Ive ever taken.

Yes!! It was so inspiring to learn about how the original Stonewall protest movements were so closely tied to and shared a lot of member overlap with civil rights, anti-colonialism, anti-capitalist, and Marxist activist and protest groups, and why all of those causes are interconnected. Professor Ferguson does an incredible job at explaining how single-issue politics hurts everyone involved and how we can draw upon direct action protest techniques today. Readings are short but Professor Ferguson does an incredible close-reading of them in lecture to show how much is packed into and what we can learn from oral histories and speeches.
Yes and I already have. This course was a great overview of queer and trans politics and I learned so much. The tfs were smart and engaging and the lectures were interesting and thought-provoking.

I would recommend this course to another student who wants an introduction to the histories of trans and queer politics in the U.S. and who hasn't taken any WGSS course (or a similar class) in the past. One thing I would say is that this course feels more suited to be a seminar than a lecture.
YES
Yes, I would recommend this course to every student at Yale.
yes yes, 100% yes!
Absolutely

Yes! Especially if you don't know much about queer history and politics, this course is a stunning introduction. WITP feels so different in its philosophical approach to learning to other courses at Yale: this class encourages you to think beyond the normative institutional logics of Yale to derive deeper truths about yourself and the world around you: I absolutely recommend it.
YES.

Yes. I would recommend this course to anyone interested in expanding their perspective to understand the experiences of others. I think the material is important for everyone to know so that long-marginalized communities do not remain pushed to the sidelines.

Yes, but do not take it if you are not interested in the material or just want a gut. You will waste your time and everybody's time if you have nothing to contribute. You should take it if you are actually interested in queer history, otherwise, it is so obvious you do not want to be there.

Yes!!! This was such an excellent, fun, enlightening, and engaging class! The TFs and Professor Ferguson create a learning environment that is both incredibly academically interesting and engaging while also super manageable and as stress-free as possible. It was by far one of the best courses I have taken because of how I was able to engage with amazing course concepts and readings and produce worthwhile and proud-worthy work related to them while not having to worry about the grading.

I would absolutely recommend this class! Professor Ferguson's thinking is brilliant, and the readings curated are so so interesting. Together I think they create a space for the thinking, reflection, and insight so critical to understanding and resisting injustice in all forms.
ABSOLUTELY, take it
I would definitely recommend it! I learned a lot in a short amount of time and the workload felt manageable. The sources we encountered were really interesting.

Yes! It is such a great overview while still being thorough about topics including queer liberation, intersectionality, abolition, and Third Worldism. The pacing is great to keep up with while you still get a lot out of it, and Professor Ferguson is really engaging during lecture.
yes!
YES!
Yes! One of the best classes Ive taken.
Absolutely. It was one of my favorite courses.

Yes 100% please take its An amazing class that doesnt have a high workload and they all want you to succeed. If you take it please go to the lectures because theres a lot to learn and Professor Ferguson is fantastic

I would definitely recommend this course to another student! Being able to learn the history behind queer liberation with a strong emphasis on the idea that queer liberation is also a fight toward liberation for BIPOC, sex workers, and other oppressed communities is what makes this course really interesting. Professor Ferguson's lectures left me in awe every week, as he always has something really insightful to say.
I would! It was very well taught and the lecture was great.
Yes, you get to learn a lot, and you have a lot of flexiblity in what you decide to write your final project on.

Yes absolutely. Not only is the course material very interesting but the way it is formatted is way more flexible and forgiving and therefore more conducive to healthy learning and understanding than any other classes Ive taken at yale.
Yes, without a doubt. It bring lights to the urgency surrounding queer and trans politics.
YES! This was a great extra course that kept me engaged in class while also not having a very heavy workload.

Yes I would recommend this course! It gives you a great amount of uncommon knowledge about LGBTQ revolutions and revolutionaries, especially about popular events like the Stonewall Riots. The course also frequently includes capitalism into the conversation which helps you understand why we see a lot of the things we see today.
